story:
(Video is only available on a computer...watch in HD for best quality)

15% OF ALL FUNDS RAISED GO TO SEAMERCY.ORG FOR THE FIJI DISASTER RELIEF FUND

*Pictures of "Perks" available towards the bottom of this page. If you want to purchase one of the perks you have to select which one you would like...or you can donate by selecting the donation button above. 

Keeping the dream alive!

So many of us grow up with dreams as children and even as young adults, most of these remain unfulfilled though or never even pursued. I have had a lot of dreams over the years, but sailing around the world was not one of them, until four years ago when I watched a film called Deep Water (It was the famous story of the 1968 Golden Globe Race in which ten amateur sailors attempted to race solo around the world), which sparked my interest. Most inspirational stories usually have a punch line or good ending, this one is more about the troubles the men faced at sea physically and mentally, but it brought a sense of physical awareness and way of thinking I never experienced. Looking back on it, as I sit here rolling side to side off the South Coast of Tahiti, I realize that all of these men lacked purpose in their quest to sail around the world, which is why most of them lost their mind (literally and figuratively). They were out to achieve a goal that would only measure themselves and not anyone else, although this was in fact the point of the race itself! A man by the name of Bernard Moitessier was about to win after 10 months at sea, but he decided to keep sailing all the way to Polynesia, in almost the exact spot I sit now. He realized that he could easily win both the cash and title, but returning to his hometown Plymouth would not make him happy, so he decided to keep on sailing.

I had just started sailing a few months before when I decided to buy my sailing boat in 2013. The idea was I would get a boat and sail it around the world, but being solo was not the original intention. It was really a pipe dream fueled by ambition to do something great and embrace a life that was full of excitement. My life before this entailed a bit of wanderlust that was filled with all different walks of life, in a variety of cities across the U.S., so for those that know me, it was not a surprise that I would take on such an endeavor. 

Once I learned the basics of sailing, I set off down the Columbia River and landed in a tiny harbor called Ilwaco. I spent two months in this coastal fishing town working on the boat, speaking with all kinds of seafaring men, and even took a sea trial to Greymouth, Washington. While I was not mentally ready for heading offshore just yet, the boat was well equipped so I decided to press on. I gathered a couple crew: the previous owner of the boat (a good sailor) and my girlfriend at the time who never sailed before. It took us 8 days to reach San Francisco (a long sea trial!)  after enduring heavy winds and seas, and from that point on I knew I could do this…but not quite alone. In the meantime I fixed the boat up after breaking a number of things and rounded up another couple crewmembers, who both had never been offshore. We set off down the coast and eventually arrived in Los Angeles where they would disembark. Once in Los Angeles I was feeling pretty confident at this point handling the boat alone, but the Baja Peninsula was still quite intimidating so I found one crew member and took off to Mexico. Once we reached Cabo San Lucas, my crewmember was becoming a challenge so I decided it was time to try being alone and sailed solo into an almost deadly storm. I was stuck with 35+ knot winds and 8-foot seas for over 12 hours, extremely close to shore…but this was the icebreaker and so off I went!  

I crossed the Sea of Cortez alone in late February and on April 1st, 2015 I cast my dock lines off from Puerto Vallarta, Mexico to begin a solo circumnavigation and cross the biggest stretch of Pacific Ocean there is. I was excited and nervous, but even more anxious for what the adventure would entail. I remember the feeling of pure joy when the first night settled in and the land slowly disappeared in the sunset... there was no turning back. 

 I didn't understand much about the sea before I left, in terms of sailing, but had a close relationship with it from a young age, when I witnessed 3 relatives drown of the coast of Charleston, South Carolina. This taught me the power of Mother Nature and also to be respectful of the natural environment, but didn't hold me back from learning to surf off the Oregon Coast. Now that I have sailed over 10,000 miles I have gained a deep affection for the ocean and truly love being a part of its magic, although sometimes it can be a bit ill tempered and unforgiving.

Last year as I made my way through the Pacific, I began to experience a variety of problems with the boat and later turned out to be more expensive than I had anticipated. After arriving to the Marquesas in April, I noticed my paint on the side of the hull was peeling back and also had a small crack below the mast in what they call the bulkhead or mast beam reinforcement. While both issues were not immediate problems I decided it would be best to haul the boat in Papeete, Tahiti in July when I arrived. While I was hauled out I found that the paint on the bottom was in need of complete stripping, along with a complete rudder rebuild which was delaminating, and the pins holding it to the boat were completely snapped. 

In order to fix this I had to fly one of my brother's out to help, which was expensive, but still cheaper then hiring someone at the yard for such a big undertaking. Over the course of 4 weeks I stripped and repainted the entire boat, repaired the rudder along with its gudgeons and pinions, replaced two of the seacocks, replaced the float switch and bilge pump, and tackled a variety of other small projects. This undertaking cost over $6000 USD and was estimated by the boat yard owner that it was a $15,000 USD project had I used their labor, so was well worth the time invested.

 Unfortunately when I was working in the boatyard back in August, a car hit me on my skateboard while running an errand and left me with a broken left arm, that turned out to be very problematic (especially when falling off scaffolding two days later and getting a concussion!). After finishing in the boat yard with a broken arm and getting Antares settled back in the water, I figured it would be best to leave the boat. I was in a full cast up to my shoulder and there was no way I would be sailing anytime soon. The French government here only gives American’s a 3-month visa and I was already two months overdue. As soon as I was out of my cast they were going to ask me to leave in the beginning of cyclone season, making it too dangerous to sail.  

I decided instead to fly to New Zealand where I could obtain a long-stay visa to French Polynesia, which would allow me to return with the boat for the remainder of cyclone season. Part of the reason I chose NZ was to obtain my Captain's License through the Mahurangi Technical Institute, a well respected maritime training facility. After sailing almost 10,000 miles the past 2 years I acquired enough sea time to qualify for my Yachtmaster’s Certificate (Offshore), but it was no easy feat to obtain. The licenses I received are issued through Royal Yacht Association (RYA) and the Maritime CoastGuard Agency (MCA), which now allow me to act as a commercial skipper aboard any sailing vessel up to 200 gross tons. It required attentive navigation, proper boat handling and docking, and a wide variety of seamanship skills. It seemed like the right thing to do and now that I have it, I can secure a job on a boat anywhere around the world. I am hoping that after I complete my trip I can utilize my experience and licenses to begin my business. For the time being I am focusing my attention on completing my circumnavigation, because I have put so much work and time into getting Antares sea worthy.

Before I left California I also had some serious upgrades that were necessary for being single handed and to keep Antares reliable and safe. These upgrades included a Norvane-Windvane (last one broke!), VHF with AIS (so I can see other vessels), Garmin Chartplotter & Radar (GPS beats using a sextant!), 200-watts of Solar Power, 4-Person Liferaft (never know!), Satellite Phone & Rescue EPIRB (to keep in touch with the outside world), & a dinghy so I could reliably get to shore. While these were all expected expenses before I left I still have some serious projects to tackle as I continue around the world. 

Antares is celebrating her 50th birthday this year and requires the utmost attention to detail. Since being in the tropics and enduring weeks of rain and strong winds, the deck below the mast has begun to separate even more, so I am going to have to pull the mast at some point in the following months. This is no small feat I am undertaking and realize there are many risks involved, which is why I want to make sure things are in working order. To do this I also need to make sure my main mode of power, the sails, are working efficiently and are reliable. Right now the main sail (almost 15 years old) has been patched in numerous places and begun to show signs of serious wear from the tropical heat. The front sail (Jib or Genoa) was already replaced after it was ripped sailing into Tahiti from the Tuamotus. I was able to pick up a Genoa from a sailmaker here who had to cut the hanks (clips) off and sewed the old luff tape onto this sail. While it works for the time being, it is cut so high that makes trying to attach a pole to the tack almost impossible, which is not safe while underway in any sort of heavy seas. 

NOW THAT I HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFUL MAKING IT THIS FAR…HERE IS WHAT'S HAPPENING NEXT! 

It’s close to 50 years after the Golden Globe Race of 1968 and I share some of the same feelings as Moitessier once did, and that is not return to the same life I lived before. For almost two years now and it has given me the chance to explore a variety of cultures and ways of life, along with learning more about myself. I realize now that the most important aspect of all this is what you can take away from it. It’s how you can interact and share ideas with various cultures along the way, the type of people you influence, and more importantly the people that you share moments with. I recently graduated with an environmental science degree in 2014 and focused a lot of my attention on water issues over the past years, so have learned valuable insight into the major problems that face our society. As a sailor I see a lot of sailing boats on the water (FACT: over 10,000 ships are out at sea at any given moment around the world!) yet most of the sailors don’t set out to assist in anyway or contribute to scientific research, it is for mere pleasure. Of course sailing for pleasure is the point of the whole thing, but for me I want it to be more than just sailing. One of the coolest and most interesting parts about sailing around the world though is that you get the chance to visit some of the most remote places on earth. You can also witness some of the human influence on the sea such as plastics, coral degradation, water pollution, etc… As I continue my circumnavigation from this point on, I am going to be focusing my time while on land and at sea to engage in scientific research or volunteer work that can aid the communities from an environmental standpoint.

I'm gearing up to cross sail west to Australia in April and will be making a major stopover in Fiji for the month of May to assist in a disaster relief effort from Cyclone Winston. I will be working with the organization called SEA MERCY. Once I arrive there I we will be repairing and building rainwater catchment systems along with delivering a variety of tools and supplies. I will probably spend around 4-8 weeks there assisting in the relief efforts before I continue on. Including the time I spend volunteering, I will be donating 5% of all my funds raised directly to a community as the organization see’s fit.

At the moment I am undecided which route I will to take after Fiji, but the goal is to sail to South Africa by the end of 2016 and complete the circumnavigation by mid 2017 (depending on weather, circumstances, and the opportunities that arise it is all subject to change).  This means I have a lot of sailing to do in the following months so here is the tentative plan…

o  April – June 2016 – Tahiti to Fiji (Assist in disaster relief)

o  June – August 2016 – Fiji to Cairns, Australia (Volunteering or other opportunities to conduct research along the way)

o  September – November 2016 – Australia to South Africa (Refit in Australia)

**I will bypass the Suez Canal Due to potential instability in the region and the fact I will be sailing alone makes it dangerous with the amount of traffic.

o  December 2016 – January 2017 – South Africa to Brazil

o  March – April 2017 – Brazil to Caribbean

o  April  - June 2017 – Caribbean to La Paz, Mexico

SO WHAT'S ALL THIS MONEY FOR? 

I'm not going to lie, this whole sailing business is a lot more expensive than I expected, which is where your generosity and support comes in. I am working on developing Lifeline Explorers into a full-fledged business by the end of this trip, but in the meantime I have no income except for some side projects for friends boats.  As Charles Bukowski said,"If you are going to try, go all the way, otherwise don't even start". With that said, I don't think now is the time to stop this trip. The way I see it is I have the boat, my health, desire, and knowledge …I just need your help to finish!

How much money do I need?: $12,000

What's it going to be used for?:  

  • New Mainsail: $2500 
  • New Headsail / Genoa: $1500 
        **Sailmaker to be used is undetermined at this point, quality and price will be                  evaluated after funds are raised** 
  • Watermaker: $2000
  • Deck / Mast Repair: $1000
  • Any remaining funds will be used for food, supplies, and visiting costs in other countries. 
  • NOTE: IndieGoGo & transaction costs total around 8% of funds raised so my funding goal is higher because of this. 

Kickbacks for your Support! 

For those of you willing to support my project and dream, your generous donations will not go unnoticed! I will be continuing to put out videos and eventually a documentary of my completed trip.

Below is a list of some of the items I can offer in exchange for your support.

In addition…15% of all funds raised be put towards the Fiji Disaster Relief fund through SeaMercy.Org

Level 1 - $5.00 (Support a Sailor)

  • Supporting a sailor on the ocean alone goes along way. You will receive a personal thank you from me via my satellite phone somewhere in the ocean. 

Level 2 - $10.00 (Postcard from around the world)

  • I’ll send you a destination Postcard from a faraway land on my route around the world.

Level 3 - $15.00 (Lifeline Explorers Sticker)

  • You will receive a Lifeline Explorers Sticker for your bumper, computer, surfboard, or whatever you choose to stick it on!

Level 3 - $25.00 (15 Minute Video Chat + Lifeline Explorers Sticker)

  • For those of you interested in learning what it's like to be sailing alone, learn about my trip or just want to chat we can Skype or FaceTime for 15 minutes + have a sticker mailed to your home.

Level 4 - $35.00 (Performance Shirt + Sticker)

  • Choose from a women's or men's performance outerwear shirt (Small - XL) + Sticker mailed to your home. Men's and Women's shirts are made of a Nylon material that is breathable, sweat resistant, and quick drying. 


Level 5 - $40.00 (Sailing Hat + Sticker)

  • Have a one time production of a lightweight hat (One Size Fits All) + Sticker mailed to your home. The hat is also quick drying and UV resistant.

Level 6 - $70 (Dry Bag + Sticker) 

  • Even if your not a sailor it could come in handy. This dry bag is air and water tight and is great for most anything. Get a dry bag + sticker mailed to your home.


Level 7 - $90.00 (High-Res Print of Teahupoo Surf Break + Sticker)

  • On July 22, 2015 a large SW swell came to Teahupoo while I was there and captured some amazing photos. Two of which were chosen by World Surf League as "Ride of the Year" and "Tube of The Year" photos. I am offering a high-res 16x20 Print + Sticker mailed to your home. Photos will be printed without any graphics. 


Level 8 - $130 (Adventure Gear Package)

  • For those of you looking to be awesome this is your chance. Your $130 would help me achieve my goals much faster and in return I will send you the Dry Bag, Hat, Shirt + Sticker.

Level 9 - $170 (2 High-Res Teahupoo Prints)

  • If you are into surf and photography this is your best bet and I would sure appreciate the support!

    I am offering both Teahupoo shots in a high-res 16x20 Print + Sticker mailed to your home.

Level 10 - $215 (Adventure Collection)

  • For those of you looking to really be a part of this whole trip and make a difference in my funding campaign this one is for you. You will be sent the hat, performance shirt (sm-xl), dry-bag, one high-res print, and of course some stickers.

Level 11 - $695 (Spend a week on Antares cruising or learning to sail!)

  • I'm not sure where the best Port will be, but I'm sure we can arrange a time for a visit. I have a few spots for those looking for a little ocean adventure or just to see what life is like living on the hook. You will of course get all the goods too, mailed to your home or to be picked up in person.


Level 12 - $1000 (BE MY SPONSOR!!)

  • It's not everyday you get the chance to sail around the world and you could be a part of it. I will have you or your company listed in my future videos (many to come), on my website, and also the chance to have your logo on promotional material. Of course you will receive a package of goodies too with 2 shirts, 2 hats, 2 dry bags, 2 prints, and 100 stickers featuring your logo!

Level 13 - $2500 (BE MY SPONSOR AND PRODUCTION ASSISTANT!)

  • This your chance to really be a part of this adventure. I will give you all the perks listed above and also the chance to offer direction in my final documentary once the trip is completed. You would also be making a big contribution to the disaster relief fund in Fiji and my trip. I will include a mailed package to your home that includes 5 shirts, 5 hats, 5 dry bags, 5 prints, and 100 stickers featuring your logo.

Why You Should Help?

  • Sailing is one of the last great adventures you can take besides flying to the moon. It is like being on a different planet at times. Through sailing I've had the opportunity to touch, see, feel, swim and photograph in some of the most remote, rugged, and isolated destinations in the world. In each of these mind-blowing locations I've had the chance to share my stories and knowledge with others, and even more importantly, I've been given the unique opportunities to meet the locals and get a glimpse of what their local culture is all about - probably the single most important part of this trip overall has been learning about the native people and cultures in French Polynesia. Many of the places I will be visiting along the way live a life not connected to the Western world and it has and will continue to provide me a chance to share ideas and explore the values of their culture. My experience learning about these cultures will be followed-up with stories and video reports available on my YouTube channel and website. 
  • I'm currently involved with disaster relief projects in Fiji, and looking to work with a number of other organizations. I'm all ears for any other volunteer or philanthropic opportunities so if you want to recommend a worthy organization feel free to send information my way! Justin@lifelineexplorers.com
  • You can follow my journey by watching my video logs and short documentaries on my website. 

Risks & Challenges

  • While there are always risks involved with sailing around the world solo, the biggest concern is that this investment could all be gone in a moment. Because of Antares' age and that fact that I am sailing solo, I'm unable to get her insured. Although I do everything I can to keep her safe, sometimes it is at the mercy of mother nature. The only thing I can do to insure that she remains afloat and is having things like the mast, deck and sails in working order. 

·  Other Ways You Can Help

·  I know sometimes you can't financially help or for that matter don't feel it is for           you to support the cause. But if you like my story or have a friend, family              or coworker with wanderlust who might want to live vicariously through me - please forward this on to them! I would greatly appreciate it! I have a feeling it's going to take a lot of work to raise the funds necessary for this trip and anything you're willing to contribute is much appreciated!

·  Please share this everywhere you can and help me spread the word about my trip! The more people that know, the better chances I have to succeed!

(Video is only available on a computer...watch in HD for best quality)

the seacocks, replaced the float switch and bilge pump, and tackled a variety
of other small projects. This undertaking cost over $6000 USD and was estimated
by the boat yard owner that it was a $15,000 USD project had I used their
labor, so was well worth the time invested.
 Unfortunately
when I was working in the boatyard back in August, a car hit me on my skateboard while running
an errand and left me with a broken left arm, that turned out to be very
problematic (especially when falling off scaffolding two days later and getting
a concussion!). After finishing in the boat yard with a broken arm and getting
Antares settled back in the water, I figured it would be best to leave the
boat. I was in a full cast up to my shoulder and there was no way I would be
sailing anytime soon. The French government here only gives American’s a 3-month
visa and I was already two months overdue. As soon as I was out of my cast they
were going to ask me to leave in the beginning of cyclone season, making it too
dangerous to sail.  
I
decided instead to fly to New Zealand where I could obtain a long-stay visa to
French Polynesia, which would allow me to return with the boat for the
remainder of cyclone season. Part of the reason I chose NZ was to obtain my
Captain's License through the Mahurangi Technical Institute, a well respected maritime training facility. After sailing
almost 10,000 miles the past 2 years I acquired enough sea time to qualify for
my Yachtmaster’s Certificate (Offshore), but it was no easy feat to obtain. The
licenses I received are issued through Royal Yacht Association (RYA) and the
Maritime CoastGuard Agency (MCA), which now allow me to act as a commercial
skipper aboard any sailing vessel up to 200 gross tons. It required attentive
navigation, proper boat handling and docking, and a wide variety of seamanship
skills. It seemed like the right thing to do and now that I have it, I can
secure a job on a boat anywhere around the world. I am hoping that after I
complete my trip I can utilize my experience and licenses to begin my business.
For the time being I am focusing my attention on completing my
circumnavigation, because I have put so much work and time into getting
Antares sea worthy. 
Before
I left California I also had some serious upgrades that were necessary for
being single handed and to keep Antares reliable and safe. These upgrades
included a Norvane-Windvane (last one broke!), VHF with AIS (so I can see other
vessels), Garmin Chartplotter & Radar (GPS beats using a sextant!),
200-watts of Solar Power, 4-Person Liferaft (never know!), Satellite Phone
& Rescue EPIRB (to keep in touch with the outside world), & a dinghy so
I could reliably get to shore. While these were all expected expenses before I
left I still have some serious projects to tackle as I continue around the
world. 
Antares
is celebrating her 50th birthday this year and requires the utmost
attention to detail. Since being in the tropics and enduring weeks of rain and
strong winds, the deck below the mast has begun to separate even more, so I am
going to have to pull the mast at some point in the following months. This is
no small feat I am undertaking and realize there are many risks involved, which
is why I want to make sure things are in working order. To do this I also need
to make sure my main mode of power, the sails, are working efficiently and are
reliable. Right now the main sail (almost 15 years old) has been patched in numerous places and begun
to show signs of serious wear from the tropical heat. The front sail (Jib or
Genoa) was already replaced after it was ripped sailing into Tahiti from the
Tuamotus. I was able to pick up a Genoa from a sailmaker here who had to cut
the hanks (clips) off and sewed the old luff tape onto this sail. While it
works for the time being, it is cut so high that makes trying to attach a pole
to the tack almost impossible, which is not safe while underway in any sort of
heavy seas. 
NOW THAT I HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFUL MAKING IT THIS
FAR…HERE IS WHAT'S HAPPENING NEXT! 

It’s
close to 50 years after the Golden Globe Race of 1968 and I share some of the same feelings as
Moitessier once did, and that is not return to the same life I lived before.
For almost two years now and it has given me the chance to explore a variety of
cultures and ways of life, along with learning more about myself. I realize now
that the most important aspect of all this is what you can take away from it.
It’s how you can interact and share ideas with various cultures along the way,
the type of people you influence, and more importantly the people that you
share moments with. I recently graduated with an environmental science degree
in 2014 and focused a lot of my attention on water issues over the past years,
so have learned valuable insight into the major problems that face our society.
As a sailor I see a lot of sailing boats on the water (FACT: over 10,000 ships
are out at sea at any given moment around the world!) yet most of the sailors
don’t set out to assist in anyway or contribute to scientific research, it is
for mere pleasure. Of course sailing for pleasure is the point of the whole thing, but for me I want it to be more than just sailing. One of the coolest and most interesting parts about sailing
around the world though is that you get the chance to visit some of the most remote
places on earth. You can also witness some of the human influence on the sea
such as plastics, coral degradation, water pollution, etc… As I continue my
circumnavigation from this point on, I am going to be focusing my time while on
land and at sea to engage in scientific research or volunteer work that can aid
the communities from an environmental standpoint. 
I'm
gearing up to cross sail west to Australia in April and will be making a major
stopover in Fiji for the month of May to assist in a disaster relief effort
from Cyclone Winston. I will be working with the organization called SEA MERCY.
Once I arrive there I we will be repairing and building rainwater catchment
systems along with delivering a variety of tools and supplies. I will
probably spend around 4-8 weeks there assisting in the relief efforts before I
continue on. Including the time I spend volunteering, I will be donating 5% of
all my funds raised directly to a community as the organization see’s fit. 
At
the moment I am undecided which route I will to take after Fiji, but the
goal is to sail to South Africa by the end of 2016 and complete the circumnavigation
by mid 2017 (depending on weather, circumstances, and the opportunities that
arise it is all subject to change).  This means I have a lot of sailing to do in the following months
so here is the tentative plan…
o  April – June 2016 – Tahiti to Fiji (Assist in disaster relief)
o  June – August 2016 – Fiji to Cairns, Australia (Volunteering or
other opportunities to conduct research along the way)
o  September – November 2016 – Australia to South Africa (Refit in Australia)
**I will bypass
the Suez Canal Due to potential instability in the region and the fact I will be
sailing alone makes it dangerous with the amount of traffic.
o  December 2016 – January 2017 – South Africa to Brazil
o  March – April 2017 – Brazil to Caribbean 
o  April  - June 2017 –
Caribbean to La Paz, Mexico
SO
WHAT'S ALL THIS MONEY FOR? 

I'm
not going to lie, this whole sailing business is a lot more expensive than I
expected, which is where your generosity and support comes in. I am working on developing
Lifeline Explorers into a full-fledged business by the end of this trip, but in
the meantime I have no income except for some side projects for friends boats.  As Charles Bukowski said,"If you
are going to try, go all the way, otherwise don't even start". With that said, I don't think now is the time to stop this trip.
The way I see it is I have the boat, my health, desire, and knowledge …I just need
your help to finish! How much money do I need?: $12,000



What's it going to be used for?:  

New
     Mainsail: $2500 
New
     Headsail / Genoa: $1500 

        **Sailmaker to be used is undetermined at this point, quality and price will be                  evaluated after funds are raised** 


Watermaker:
     $2000
Deck
     / Mast Repair: $1000
Any
     remaining funds will be used for food, supplies, and visiting costs in
     other countries. 
NOTE: IndieGoGo
     & transaction costs total around 8% of funds raised so my funding goal
     is higher because of this. 

Kickbacks
for your Support! 
For those of you willing to support my project
and dream, your generous donations will not go unnoticed! I will be continuing
to put out videos and eventually a documentary of my completed trip. 
Below is a list of some of the items I can
offer in exchange for your support.
In addition…15% of all funds raised
be put towards the Fiji Disaster Relief fund through SeaMercy.Org
Level 1 - $5.00 (Support a Sailor)

Supporting
     a sailor on the ocean alone goes along way. You will receive a personal
     thank you from me via my satellite phone somewhere in the ocean. 

Level
2 - $10.00 (Postcard from around the world)

I’ll send you a destination Postcard from a faraway land on my route around the world.

Level
3 - $15.00 (Lifeline Explorers Sticker)

You will receive a Lifeline Explorers Sticker for your bumper, computer, surfboard, or whatever you choose to stick it on!



Level 3 - $25.00 (15 Minute Video Chat + Lifeline Explorers Sticker)
For those of you interested in learning what it's like to be sailing alone, learn about my trip or just want to chat we can Skype or FaceTime for 15 minutes + have a sticker mailed to your home.

Level
4 - $35.00 (Performance Shirt + Sticker)

Choose
     from a women's or men's performance outerwear shirt (Small - XL) + Sticker
     mailed to your home. Men's and Women's shirts are made of a Nylon material that is breathable, sweat resistant, and quick drying. 







Level
5 - $40.00 (Sailing Hat + Sticker)

Have
     a one time production of a lightweight hat (One Size Fits All) + Sticker
     mailed to your home. The hat is also quick drying and UV resistant.






Level 6 - $70 (Dry Bag + Sticker) 

Even if your not a sailor it could come in handy. This dry bag is air and water tight and is great for most anything. Get a dry bag + sticker mailed to your home.






Level 7 - $90.00 (High-Res Print of Teahupoo Surf Break + Sticker)
On July 22, 2015 a large SW swell came to Teahupoo while I was there and captured some amazing photos. Two of which were chosen by World Surf League as "Ride of the Year" and "Tube of The Year" photos. I am offering a high-res 16x20 Print + Sticker mailed to your home. Photos will be printed without any graphics. 






Level
8 - $130 (Adventure Gear Package)

For those of you looking to be awesome this is your chance. Your $130 would help me achieve my goals much faster and in return I will send you the Dry Bag, Hat, Shirt + Sticker.


Level 9 - $170 (2 High-Res Teahupoo Prints)

If you are into surf and photography this is your best bet and I would sure appreciate the support!
I am offering both Teahupoo shots in a high-res 16x20 Print + Sticker mailed to your home.



Level 10 - $215 (Adventure Collection)

For those of you looking to really be a part of this whole trip and make a difference in my funding campaign this one is for you. You will be sent the hat, performance shirt (sm-xl), dry-bag, one high-res print, and of course some stickers.



Level 11 - $695 (Spend a week on Antares cruising or learning to sail!)

I'm not sure where the best Port will be, but I'm sure we can arrange a time for a visit. I have a few spots for those looking for a little ocean adventure or just to see what life is like living on the hook. You will of course get all the goods too, mailed to your home or to be picked up in person.







Level 12 - $1000 (BE MY SPONSOR!!)

It's not everyday you get the chance to sail around the world and you could be a part of it. I will have you or your company listed in my future videos (many to come), on my website, and also the chance to have your logo on promotional material. Of course you will receive a package of goodies too with 2 shirts, 2 hats, 2 dry bags, 2 prints, and 100 stickers featuring your logo!

Level
13 - $2500 (BE MY SPONSOR AND PRODUCTION ASSISTANT!)

This your chance to really be a part of this adventure. I will give you all the perks listed above and also the chance to offer direction in my final documentary once the trip is completed. You would also be making a big contribution to the disaster relief fund in Fiji and my trip. I will include a mailed package to your home that includes 5 shirts, 5 hats, 5 dry bags, 5 prints, and 100 stickers featuring your logo.



Why
You Should Help?

Sailing
     is one of the last great adventures you can take besides flying to the
     moon. It is like being on a different planet at times. Through sailing
     I've had the opportunity to touch, see, feel, swim and photograph in some
     of the most remote, rugged, and isolated destinations in the world. In
     each of these mind-blowing locations I've had the chance to share my
     stories and knowledge with others, and even more importantly, I've been
     given the unique opportunities to meet the locals and get a glimpse of
     what their local culture is all about - probably the single most important
     part of this trip overall has been learning about the native people and
     cultures in French Polynesia. Many of the places I will be visiting along
     the way live a life not connected to the Western world and it has and will
     continue to provide me a chance to share ideas and explore the values of
     their culture. My experience learning about these cultures will be
     followed-up with stories and video reports available on my YouTube channel
     and website.  
I'm
     currently involved with disaster relief projects in Fiji, and looking to work with a number of other organizations. I'm all ears for any other
     volunteer or philanthropic opportunities so if you want to recommend a
     worthy organization feel free to send information my way! Justin@lifelineexplorers.com

You
     can follow my journey by watching my video logs and short documentaries on
     my website.  

Risks
& Challenges

While
     there are always risks involved with sailing around the world solo, the
     biggest concern is that this investment could all be gone in a moment.
     Because of Antares' age and that fact that I am sailing solo, I'm unable to get her insured. Although I do everything I can to
     keep her safe, sometimes it is at the mercy of mother nature. The only thing I can do to insure that she remains afloat and is having things like the mast, deck and sails in working order. 

· 
Other Ways You Can Help
·  I know sometimes you can't financially help or for that matter
don't feel it is for           you to support the cause. But if you like my story or have
a friend, family              or coworker with wanderlust who might want to live vicariously
through me - please forward this on to them! I would greatly appreciate it! I
have a feeling it's going to take a lot of work to raise the funds necessary
for this trip and anything you're willing to contribute is much appreciated!
· 
Please share this everywhere you can
and help me spread the word about my trip! The more people that know, the
better chances I have to succeed!

story:
Short Summary

I am Jules Mitchell,  a  16 year old Laser sailor who loves to race and represent my country, Antigua.  I really want to compete in the 2015 Laser Worlds this August in Canada.  I have been sailing since 2009 and have been competing in the Laser Radial class since 2013.  Competing in Laser Worlds in another step in my long journey to get to the 2020 Olympics.  I have competed in local, regional and international regattas and would not get to do that without the support of my family, friends and well wishers who all want to see me succeed.  The support means a lot to me and I am grateful for it every day.  I work hard at my sport as it requires an advanced level of fitness to endure the straight legged hiking and body-torque techniques that are so necessary to getting upwind and reaching quickly.  I am working towards being as fit and ready as I can be for the Laser Worlds in August and appreciate all the support I can get.  If my campaign is successful, I want to represent Antigua and show that Antiguan sailors have skills.  I know that I am young, but if I can get there, I will show that I have what it takes.  
The cost of getting to the Laser Worlds:
Entry Fee -               $395.00
Boat Rental -           $665.00
Pre Charter -            $475.00
Damage Deposit -  $400.00
Insurance -               $   45.00
Coach -  12 days     $ 600.00
Coach boat  -           $  500.00
Airfare  (Approx) -  $1150.00
Accom. and food -  $ 600.00
Transport -                $ 200.00
The cost of the coach and coach boat and the accomodation and food is based on prices quoted on the information I have acquired from the host site, but these may be adjusted later as I plan to share with another country and it will bring the cost down.  For the moment though, I have to assume that the cost will be approximately US$5,000.00
If I can get corporate sponsorship, I will display your logo on my sail and boat and on my shirts.
I am trying to raise money locally, in Antigua and donations can be made to the National Sailing Academy, just put my name, Jules Mitchell, in the memo part of the cheque and give it to Elizabeth Jordan at the Academy in Falmouth, Antigua.
Not everyone can contribute financially, but you can still support me by sharing this campaign, using the Indiegogo sharing tools and making some noise about my campaign.  The more people who see it or hear about it, the more help and support I can get.  If you know me, you can let your contacts know that you know me and that I am serious about my sport and appreciate any and all help and support I can get.
With the support of my friends, family and other well wishers, I have been to the Orange Bowl Youth Regatta in Florida twice and to Jensen Beach for the Byte International and Olympic qualifier.  I have been to many regionals like Tortola and St. Maaarten and most recently to Martinique, their Sailing Festival Semaine de Schoelcher where I placed 3rd in my class and it was not a youth regatta. I could not do any of this without your support and so I thank you and ask for  your continued support,  
I am really excited about Laser Worlds and hope with your help, we can make it happen.

The cost of the coach and coach boat and the accomodation and food is based on prices quoted on the information I have acquired from the host site, but these may be adjusted later as I plan to share with another country and it will bring the cost down.  For the moment though, I have to assume that the cost will be approximately US$5,000.00
If I can get corporate sponsorship, I will display your logo on my sail and boat and on my shirts.
I am trying to raise money locally, in Antigua and donations can be made to the National Sailing Academy, just put my name, Jules Mitchell, in the memo part of the cheque and give it to Elizabeth Jordan at the Academy in Falmouth, Antigua.
Not everyone can contribute financially, but you can still support me by sharing this campaign, using the Indiegogo sharing tools and making some noise about my campaign.  The more people who see it or hear about it, the more help and support I can get.  If you know me, you can let your contacts know that you know me and that I am serious about my sport and appreciate any and all help and support I can get.
With the support of my friends, family and other well wishers, I have been to the Orange Bowl Youth Regatta in Florida twice and to Jensen Beach for the Byte International and Olympic qualifier.  I have been to many regionals like Tortola and St. Maaarten and most recently to Martinique, their Sailing Festival Semaine de Schoelcher where I placed 3rd in my class and it was not a youth regatta. I could not do any of this without your support and so I thank you and ask for  your continued support,  

I am really excited about Laser Worlds and hope with your help, we can make it happen.

story:
Note: Shipping is NOT free and will be charged later via Backerkit survey








Watch this quick unboxing video to see what comes with every Lumos Ultra and how it works.




 

Lumos Ultra will also come with an option to add MIPS. This is an extra safety feature that is built into the helmet to add protection against rotational motion transferred to the brain. Rotational motion affects the brain and increase the risk for minor and severe brain injuries.

 

 


 

Chips On Board (COB) is a method of LED packaging which has a number of advantages over more conventional technologies. It allows for a more compact footprint whilst delivering a higher intensity of light meaning you’ll be seen from further away. It is also what gives the lights a more uniform look. We like to think of it as Currently Our Best LED technology.

 

 

It’s our most vented helmet yet. We’ve been listening to customer feedback and have paid very close attention to the way Ultra directs air through its internal venting system. We’ve created 3 enormous exhausts in the rear to ensure hot air gets pushed out helping to keep the rider cool whether on a commute or on a training session.

 

 

We’ve already done the initial crash tests on our beta units and they pass with plenty of safety margin to spare. We’re confident that Ultra will be one of the safest helmets on road even without the lights on.

 

 

When you ride, you must be prepared to ride in any weather. That's why Ultra is built to IPX6 standards, to withstand the elements and keep you riding bright, come rain or shine.

 

 

We've worked really hard to improve the weight of our smart helmets. By using more efficient manufacturing methods, we were able to use less material without compromising the high level of protection that our helmets provide. Our very first helmet weighed in at 490 grams, Ultra is estimated to have a final weight of 370 grams. Now that's a big win (or loss).

 


 

There are multiple benefits to wearing lights high up on the head. Firstly, it makes it possible to be seen more clearly by motorists on the road. You're less likely to encounter a situation where your lights are being blocked by parked cars or other things on the road. Secondly, by illuminating your head, it's much easier for motorists to see where you're looking and thus know approach more carefully.

 

 


 

Ultra is the helmet for everyone, from kids to even bigger kids. It is available in the sizes S, M-L and XL, and they are all equipped with a click-dial fit system to ensure that Ultra sits firmly yet comfortably on your head.

  • Small (S): 51-55 cm / 20-21.6 in
  • Medium to Large (M-L): 54-61 cm / 21.3-24 in
  • Extra Large (XL): 61-65 cm / 24-25.6 in

 


 

 

 

 


 

Despite starting with a design brief of creating the successor to the wildly popular Kickstart helmet, but at half the cost, the design of Ultra has been a labour of love. We could’ve just taken the simpler approach of cutting costs from the Kickstart helmet, but we wanted to create a helmet that takes all of our learnings from building smart wearables and push the limits of helmet design to completely new heights. We’ve agonized over all the small details refining them to the point where they’d feel more at home on a $200+ helmet.

Just a few of the things we’ve considered include a design that’s not too overstated, yet exudes style. We’ve taken an even more focused user-centric approach to consider useful extras such as the sun visor and overall weight, as well as taking a keen interest in venting to help keep the head cool on more demanding rides. We’re super stoked about how the design has progressed over Ultra’s development cycle, and know that our customers will appreciate the attention to detail once they get the product in their hands.

 

 

From sketches, to CAD, to 3D printed models and design validation beta prototypes, we are now in the final stages of the design process. We are collecting tons of valuable feedback and are working on refinements to release the perfect product. With each new version, we get closer to the ultimate helmet for cycling.




We've completed our beta testing phase. These are some of the pictures and feedback we've gotten from our beta testers.



Better styling, amazing air flow and a shockingly lower price. Lumos Ultra really deserves the name, and frankly should be selling like hot cakes. The Lumos Ultra shows how the brand has matured from its Kickstarter roots into an established and innovative company. — James Gill, Nuneaton, UK


Honestly having lights on your helmet is life changing.. The thing I like best is that if I have any doubt about whether a driver has seen me, I can look at them or their rear view mirror and know the light will flash right at them. — Caterina Buizza, London, UK


Not only will you will be investing in your safety, but you will also be getting a premium helmet. Ultra is light and breathable. It’s innovative, giving you THAT thing that other helmets are missing. I love how it looks awesome and really feels great. — Francisco Garcia, New York


For anyone that was on the fence with the previous products due to price, hopefully this new version makes the decision much easier. Just as effective as the previous versions in terms of safety (see and be seen), but with a sleek new design and more accessible price point? What’s not to like….! — John Yu, San Francisco


This is by far the best helmet if you want great protective gear, slick looks -and- lights. With the lights on your head they are above car roofs so they can always be seen. The cool look, the ventilation and the lightweight, non-bothering fit makes this my A+ choice for my 100 k per day commute as well as for ride my race bike or going on trails with my kids. — Henrik Becker, Germany


I love the concept of the Lumos helmet. I’m pretty sure my previous Lumos helmet saved my life before. The Ultra feels like a totally normal helmet. The price is reasonable for any helmet and it looks like a helmet I would buy even if it didn’t have lights. Throw in the lights and it’s totally a no-brainer! Everyone should have one! — David Rolfe, San Francisco


It’s obvious that Lumos Ultra was built on love and experience.
I have been following Lumos products since the first helmet came out on Kickstarter, and I believe the Ultra is the best one yet. It looks really cool, is super comfortable to wear, and feels very light on my head. As a surgeon, I have to go to the hospital at odd hours, lots of midnights and early mornings.. Since I’ve had the Ultra helmet, I am more confident in cycling to work. The bright lights and turn signals makes me feel more visible on the road, and visible is safe! In broad daylight, the smooth design and good-looking colors turns a lot of heads! — Petra Wahjoepramono, Indonesia


Are you are looking for a helmet that gives you the best protection both day and night? Look no further! Lumos Ultra is lightweight, high quality, durable and has the most awesome front and tail lights customization that other similar helmets only can only dream of. — Stijn Buyse, Belgium


This is the Tesla of bike helmets. Style functionality, safety features and comfort. It’s unlike any helmet I have seen on the road. This is the future of bike helmets. — Grant Leslie, Australia

 

 

Note:

Due to the large order of helmets currently, we cannot ship all the helmets at the same time. Hence the long duration of Mass Production to Delivery from Sept 2020 to April 2021, during which we will ship out helmets weekly.

*Helmets for Indiegogo/In-Demand customers will likely have their helmets shipped out starting early 2021.

As this is an estimate, timelines may get pushed up or pushed back but we will give our 100% to make sure that things are completed on, or even ahead of schedule.

 

At the end of the campaign, we will send you a Backerkit survey via email.

From there, you will be able to choose your: Color, MIPS-add on, size, visor and other add-ons we might release throughout the campaign.

MIPS

If you have already purchased the Lumos Ultra MIPS reward, you will not need to add MIPS in the survey. It will be assigned to you automatically.

However, if you have bought the standard Lumos Ultra, you will still be able to purchase the MIPS add-on for the difference in price between the rewards.

Size

We will be launching Ultra in small (S: 51-55 cm/20-21.6 in), medium to large (M-L: 54-61 cm/21.3-24 in) and extra large sizes (XL: 61-65 cm/24-25.6 in) so that anyone from kids to adults can have an Ultra. You will be able to choose the size you want through the Backerkit survey we send you at the end of the campaign.

Visor

You will also be able to add on the attachable visor if you decide that you need one for your daily ride. The visor will retail for $25, but for this campaign, we are launching it at only $14.95.

Other add-ons

We are currently working on some Lumos merchandise, ranging from other cycling gear to everyday wear items. Once we lock down the designs and start building prototypes, we will share them with you! You will also be able to buy these add-ons through the Backerkit survey.

 

Shipping, Taxes (and VAT) will be calculated and paid for towards the end of the campaign, before we ship the helmets out to you. During these uncertain times, shipping costs have gone up significantly, however, we do believe that the prices will go down as the situation gets better globally.

Hence, we do not think charging shipping right now, upon pledging is at the interest of our supporters as the prices today might be more expensive than that in a few months time.

Here are our estimates of what shipping would be.

* Prices do not include taxes and VAT. That will be subject to the laws and regulations of each individual country.

 ** Note that these prices are dependent on the situation and may increase or decrease by a few dollars in the months to come.

"I don't see my country as a shipping option" : If you do not see your country as a shipping option, it means that we currently do not offer shipping to that country. However, do send us an email if you are from a country that is not shown above, we'd love to know about it. If enough of you request for it such that it makes sense logistically to ship to that country, we will add it as an option later.


⬆️ Back to top ⬆️
story_txt:
Note: Shipping is NOT free and will be charged later via Backerkit surveyWatch this quick unboxing video to see what comes with every Lumos Ultra and how it works.Lumos Ultra comes included with a wireless handlebar remote to make signalling as easy as pressing a button.Got an Apple watch? You can control the turn signals on Lumos Ultra by simply raising your arm.Keep the sun and rain out of your eyes while you ride with an optional attachable visor. Lumos Ultra will also come with an option to add MIPS. This is an extra safety feature that is built into the helmet to add protection against rotational motion transferred to the brain. Rotational motion affects the brain and increase the risk for minor and severe brain injuries.   Chips On Board (COB) is a method of LED packaging which has a number of advantages over more conventional technologies. It allows for a more compact footprint whilst delivering a higher intensity of light meaning you’ll be seen from further away. It is also what gives the lights a more uniform look. We like to think of it as Currently Our Best LED technology.  It’s our most vented helmet yet. We’ve been listening to customer feedback and have paid very close attention to the way Ultra directs air through its internal venting system. We’ve created 3 enormous exhausts in the rear to ensure hot air gets pushed out helping to keep the rider cool whether on a commute or on a training session.  We’ve already done the initial crash tests on our beta units and they pass with plenty of safety margin to spare. We’re confident that Ultra will be one of the safest helmets on road even without the lights on.  When you ride, you must be prepared to ride in any weather. That's why Ultra is built to IPX6 standards, to withstand the elements and keep you riding bright, come rain or shine.  We've worked really hard to improve the weight of our smart helmets. By using more efficient manufacturing methods, we were able to use less material without compromising the high level of protection that our helmets provide. Our very first helmet weighed in at 490 grams, Ultra is estimated to have a final weight of 370 grams. Now that's a big win (or loss).  There are multiple benefits to wearing lights high up on the head. Firstly, it makes it possible to be seen more clearly by motorists on the road. You're less likely to encounter a situation where your lights are being blocked by parked cars or other things on the road. Secondly, by illuminating your head, it's much easier for motorists to see where you're looking and thus know approach more carefully.   Ultra is the helmet for everyone, from kids to even bigger kids. It is available in the sizes S, M-L and XL, and they are all equipped with a click-dial fit system to ensure that Ultra sits firmly yet comfortably on your head.
Small (S): 51-55 cm / 20-21.6 in
Medium to Large (M-L): 54-61 cm / 21.3-24 in
Extra Large (XL): 61-65 cm / 24-25.6 in
   

   Despite starting with a design brief of creating the successor to the wildly popular Kickstart helmet, but at half the cost, the design of Ultra has been a labour of love. We could’ve just taken the simpler approach of cutting costs from the Kickstart helmet, but we wanted to create a helmet that takes all of our learnings from building smart wearables and push the limits of helmet design to completely new heights. We’ve agonized over all the small details refining them to the point where they’d feel more at home on a $200+ helmet.Just a few of the things we’ve considered include a design that’s not too overstated, yet exudes style. We’ve taken an even more focused user-centric approach to consider useful extras such as the sun visor and overall weight, as well as taking a keen interest in venting to help keep the head cool on more demanding rides. We’re super stoked about how the design has progressed over Ultra’s development cycle, and know that our customers will appreciate the attention to detail once they get the product in their hands.  From sketches, to CAD, to 3D printed models and design validation beta prototypes, we are now in the final stages of the design process. We are collecting tons of valuable feedback and are working on refinements to release the perfect product. With each new version, we get closer to the ultimate helmet for cycling.We've completed our beta testing phase. These are some of the pictures and feedback we've gotten from our beta testers.Better styling, amazing air flow and a shockingly lower price. Lumos Ultra really deserves the name, and frankly should be selling like hot cakes. The Lumos Ultra shows how the brand has matured from its Kickstarter roots into an established and innovative company. — James Gill, Nuneaton, UKHonestly having lights on your helmet is life changing.. The thing I like best is that if I have any doubt about whether a driver has seen me, I can look at them or their rear view mirror and know the light will flash right at them. — Caterina Buizza, London, UKNot only will you will be investing in your safety, but you will also be getting a premium helmet. Ultra is light and breathable. It’s innovative, giving you THAT thing that other helmets are missing. I love how it looks awesome and really feels great. — Francisco Garcia, New YorkFor anyone that was on the fence with the previous products due to price, hopefully this new version makes the decision much easier. Just as effective as the previous versions in terms of safety (see and be seen), but with a sleek new design and more accessible price point? What’s not to like….! — John Yu, San FranciscoThis is by far the best helmet if you want great protective gear, slick looks -and- lights. With the lights on your head they are above car roofs so they can always be seen. The cool look, the ventilation and the lightweight, non-bothering fit makes this my A+ choice for my 100 k per day commute as well as for ride my race bike or going on trails with my kids. — Henrik Becker, GermanyI love the concept of the Lumos helmet. I’m pretty sure my previous Lumos helmet saved my life before. The Ultra feels like a totally normal helmet. The price is reasonable for any helmet and it looks like a helmet I would buy even if it didn’t have lights. Throw in the lights and it’s totally a no-brainer! Everyone should have one! — David Rolfe, San FranciscoIt’s obvious that Lumos Ultra was built on love and experience.I have been following Lumos products since the first helmet came out on Kickstarter, and I believe the Ultra is the best one yet. It looks really cool, is super comfortable to wear, and feels very light on my head. As a surgeon, I have to go to the hospital at odd hours, lots of midnights and early mornings.. Since I’ve had the Ultra helmet, I am more confident in cycling to work. The bright lights and turn signals makes me feel more visible on the road, and visible is safe! In broad daylight, the smooth design and good-looking colors turns a lot of heads! — Petra Wahjoepramono, IndonesiaAre you are looking for a helmet that gives you the best protection both day and night? Look no further! Lumos Ultra is lightweight, high quality, durable and has the most awesome front and tail lights customization that other similar helmets only can only dream of. — Stijn Buyse, BelgiumThis is the Tesla of bike helmets. Style functionality, safety features and comfort. It’s unlike any helmet I have seen on the road. This is the future of bike helmets. — Grant Leslie, Australia  Note:Due to the large order of helmets currently, we cannot ship all the helmets at the same time. Hence the long duration of Mass Production to Delivery from Sept 2020 to April 2021, during which we will ship out helmets weekly.*Helmets for Indiegogo/In-Demand customers will likely have their helmets shipped out starting early 2021.As this is an estimate, timelines may get pushed up or pushed back but we will give our 100% to make sure that things are completed on, or even ahead of schedule. At the end of the campaign, we will send you a Backerkit survey via email.From there, you will be able to choose your: Color, MIPS-add on, size, visor and other add-ons we might release throughout the campaign.MIPSIf you have already purchased the Lumos Ultra MIPS reward, you will not need to add MIPS in the survey. It will be assigned to you automatically.However, if you have bought the standard Lumos Ultra, you will still be able to purchase the MIPS add-on for the difference in price between the rewards.SizeWe will be launching Ultra in small (S: 51-55 cm/20-21.6 in), medium to large (M-L: 54-61 cm/21.3-24 in) and extra large sizes (XL: 61-65 cm/24-25.6 in) so that anyone from kids to adults can have an Ultra. You will be able to choose the size you want through the Backerkit survey we send you at the end of the campaign.VisorYou will also be able to add on the attachable visor if you decide that you need one for your daily ride. The visor will retail for $25, but for this campaign, we are launching it at only $14.95.Other add-onsWe are currently working on some Lumos merchandise, ranging from other cycling gear to everyday wear items. Once we lock down the designs and start building prototypes, we will share them with you! You will also be able to buy these add-ons through the Backerkit survey. Shipping, Taxes (and VAT) will be calculated and paid for towards the end of the campaign, before we ship the helmets out to you. During these uncertain times, shipping costs have gone up significantly, however, we do believe that the prices will go down as the situation gets better globally.Hence, we do not think charging shipping right now, upon pledging is at the interest of our supporters as the prices today might be more expensive than that in a few months time.Here are our estimates of what shipping would be.* Prices do not include taxes and VAT. That will be subject to the laws and regulations of each individual country. ** Note that these prices are dependent on the situation and may increase or decrease by a few dollars in the months to come."I don't see my country as a shipping option" : If you do not see your country as a shipping option, it means that we currently do not offer shipping to that country. However, do send us an email if you are from a country that is not shown above, we'd love to know about it. If enough of you request for it such that it makes sense logistically to ship to that country, we will add it as an option later.⬆️ Back to top ⬆️

story:
The Safest Luggage

KingNeed, the Smart Luggage Changer

What we are facing..

Of all the things that can go wrong while traveling—traffic jams, delayed or canceled flights, missed calls—none can ruin your plans like lost or stolen luggage. Your career-making business trip becomes null when the laptop containing your presentation goes missing along with the carry-on it's in. Your honeymoon vacation turns into a nightmare when the suitcase your passport was in disappears. Maybe you put the keys to your car and home in there too. What now? With all that's at risk while traveling, isn't it time your luggage got smart?


Why KingNeed’s Smart Luggage?

With KingNeed's new smart luggage, you'll never have to fear losing your luggage again. Advanced GPS+WIFI+GSM combined positioning technology is built into these durable pieces, allowing you to track their whereabouts at all times. From your phone you can look up the location of your luggage, receive alerts when it's moved, receive alerts if unauthorized opening occurs, activate a warning alarm to scare away theft, and more. With five patents, KingNeed smart luggage offers the most advanced security technology available. It is the only GPS luggage on the market available in carry-on size.

GPS+WIFI+GSM combined positioning technology

GPS+WIFI+GSM combined positioning technology allows you to quickly locate your luggage anywhere on the globe, whether it be in baggage claim or on a different continent. Open the app, and in a second, the location of your luggage will appear on your smart phone screen. Places luggage within five meters of accurate location outdoors and fifty meters indoors.


Safe Box on the go

Recent news reports of baggage handlers caught on camera rifling passengers' suitcases and stealing their valuables have made travelers more anxious than ever. KingNeed smart luggage safe box function protects against this by sending alerts to your phone in the event that anyone attempts to open it. Remote control of the luggage allows you to set this function after you see your luggage inspected by handlers at check-in and sent to storage. Once arrived at your destination, this feature can keep your valuables secure from possible theft while you are out.


Radar Find Me 

Once in the general vicinity of your luggage, the Find Me function can help you pinpoint its location. Even in the rare absence of GPS and WIFI signals, your smart luggage can still be located by searching for the wireless signal it sends. The system will broadcast this signal as a WIFI hotspot that the user can detect on a smart phone in order to get closer to the luggage. Places luggage within two meters of accurate location.

Announce Find Me 

Yet another way KingNeed smart luggage protects you from loss or theft, the Announce Find Me function triggers special audio to attract the attention of passerby and direct them to take luggage to the nearest lost and found desk.

Anti-Lost

No matter if you are working, chatting on the phone, or dozing off while traveling, your luggage is always protected by the Anti-Lost function. When you connect Bluetooth to activate this function, you will receive phone calls and SMS alerts as soon as your luggage is moved away from you. In addition, a warning alarm will sound through the built-in speaker on the luggage to scare away theft.

Ringtone Reminder & Hands-Free Calls

The hustle of a busy airport can be distracting and lead to missed calls. KingNeed smart luggage boasts a convenient hands-free call function for communicating with ease while traveling. In the event of an incoming call, your smart luggage plays a ringtone simultaneously. You can take calls directly from the luggage with its built-in speaker and receiver.

Solid Design

Built on an aluminum metal frame to withstand rough handling. Despite the advanced technology, the classic, understated design does not have a conspicuous technique or space age appearance.

KingNeed smart luggage comes in Carry-on 20 inch, and Check-in 28 inch sizes. Compliant with International Airline travel regulations.

DIY Module

Torn between the new smart technology and your favorite old luggage pieces? KingNeed has the solution. Our groundbreaking DIY module allows you to make all your luggage smart. With simple tools and easy to follow instructions, you can install all of the cutting edge technology of KingNeed smart luggage into any suitcase.


Monitor though App, SMS, or Website

All tracking information and device status alerts including location in Google maps, history playback, Geo-fence, reports, and fleet management are accessible anytime by SMS, IOS and Android Apps, or computer (Mac or PC) web page. This ensures you have the information you need no matter where you are and what device you have on hand.

Additional Features

Safe 

Smart luggage can be switched between air and land mode and conforms to the provisions of safety flight requirements.                

Global

KingNeed smart luggage supports SMS in all countries and supports global Google map display worldwide.

Cloud

Remote control your smart luggage easily by app or SMS

Best Gift for this Holidays 

We're shipping the Smart Safest Luggage DIY module at end of December to all Indiegogo backers, which makes it the perfect New Year present this year, and the Smart Luggage will be shipped at beginning  of January 2016.


GET $9 BONUS

To receive your $9 bonus, in addition to your pledge, simply follow the instructions below.

1) Share our campaign on Facebook (There is a Facebook share button on the left, or otherwise (https://www.facebook.com/kingneedpro/), please use this exact link to share.  

2) Follow us on Facebook (Search for KingNeedpro on Facebook and follow us)

3) Screen shot both the above and send it to knpromo@outlook.com from your registered Indiegogo account.  

4) Congratulations we will send you an email confirmation confirming your BONUS.


Here's why we're not just dreaming.

We think we can deliver on time, and deliver with top quality. Here's why:

  • We are professional and experienced in the SECURITY and TRACKER business, there’s no any new technique for us, we just make a combination i in the luggage field
  • We have our own R&D Team and Factory to make sure we can delivery on time
  • Our luggage supplier is the world class factory which supplies luggage with famous brand in the world 
  • We are using the best component and technique to make sure this smart luggage is the safest luggage ever in the market

story:
Quick, Easy & Safe Boat Launching and Retrieving.

 

Seriously, There’s No Catch.

Boat-Load-Mate is a rear-mounted trailer accessory mounts easily to any bunk or roller style boat trailer allowing users to safely load and unload their boat in a matter of seconds, without the use of a bow catch. Boat-Load-Mate is a game changer for people who trailer their boats. 

Boat-Load-Mate is simple to use. When launching, back your boat into the water and the boat will float safely over the latch. When loading, drive your boat onto the trailer and the spring loaded latch will engage, securing the boat until you are off the ramp. Once you are off the ramp, secure your boat as you usual would for road travel. 

Boat-Load-Mate makes boat launching & retrieving FASTER & SAFER.  By simply decreasing the time spent on the ramp, the chance for accidents and injuries is significantly reduced. Furthermore, Boat-Load-Mate is an ADA solution that increases accessibility.

WATCH THIS VIDEO. Boat-Load-Mate user is on the right hand side. 

Standard Boat Retrieval vs Boat-Load-Mate Retrieval


Over the past few years the Boat-Load-Mate has gone through a rigor process of prototyping, testing, patenting and manufacturing. Presently there are over 13 million boat trailers in use in the USA, according to the National Marine Manufacturers Association, with an estimated 11 million used for weekend transporting to local waters for day use. Our goal is to sell 150,000 units to penetrate 1.15% of the market in our first year. 

Manufacturing Completed February 2021  

And now our first order is ready to ship to customers! 

 

What You Get

By purchasing a Boat-Load-Mate and/or making a donation during this campaign:

  1. You get a 20% savings off the retail price [only for the first 100 buyers]
  2. You are supporting US manufacturing and youth programs in the community.
  3. You get reliability and safety when launching & loading your boat.  

Boat-Load-Mate comes with:

  • Base & Latch 
  • Extension Bar
  • Shim's 
  • Mounting Hardware 

 

What We Need 

Our goal is to raise $30,000 to strengthen our Boat-Load-Mate brand and generate online awareness. 

  • $15,000 for raising awareness by purchasing marketing space 
  • $10,000 for creating new marketing videos and materials
  • $5,000 donated to Mentor North. 

25% of all funding raised above our goal will be donated to Mentor North 

 

The Impact

We're excited to bring the Boat-Load-Mate to market at half the price of more complicated competitor products while also giving back!

The Boat-Load-Mate was invented for anybody who trailers a boat and uses a boat ramp.

  • Making launching and loading your boat safer and easier while decongesting boat ramps.

  • Made In The USA from Marine Grade UV resistant materials that have been proven to be environmentally sustainable from how long they last.

  • Supports programs impacting our communities.

 

 

Risks & Challenges

The Boat-Load-Mate was developed and tested within our small tight-knit fishing community. Until we experience broad consumer feedback from outside our initial market we are operating in a world of unknowns. 

The Biggest Challenges we face reaching our goal of 150,000 sales in our first year are:

  • Limited consumer feedback.
  • Limited brand recognition in boating communities.
  • Limited marketing materials tailored from feedback from our market.

Our Official Product Launch is this May and we're now creating a community around our product.

 

Honoring A Tradition of Giving Back:

We're building a Made In America brand with strong values centered around giving back to the community.

And we are starting by giving back to the amazing non-profit that nurtured the relationship that started this all. 

Boat-Load-Mate inventor Bill Scott first met James Knight, 17 years ago at the Mentor North program in Duluth, Minnesota. Throughout the years, they’ve formed a true bond around countless fishing trips, from ice fishing on Red Lake, MN to deep sea fishing in Alaska. The time they spent on the boat would prove to be the foundation for their company years later. In 2018, Bill got an idea for a quick, easy, and affordable boat launching and retrieving product. He was compelled to take action and teamed up with his mentee James to create what is now “Boat-Load-Mate.” Both Bill and James recognize the importance of youth mentorship and are committed to giving back to the Mentor North program as part of growing Boat-Load-Mate to being a success.

 

James & Bill 2009 || Bill & James 2020

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, it doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! Please Share Share Share

 

CHECK OUT OUR NON-PROFIT RECIPIENT MENTOR NORTH BY CLICKING HERE

story:
Give The Dream A little More Science and Technology, and let The Travel Go Further

 

Make your travel no longer tedious, travel more focused, more flexible, lighter, more intelligent, make the journey easier

 

Intelligent pull rod box, ergonomic design, aviation materials, anti fall, anti scratch, waterproof​

 

LM Makes Your Every Day Travel Enjoyable

 

Simple, fast, fingerprint unlock

No need to start switch, 1 second identification, safe and convenient

 

TSA global customs lock, certified by traffic safety bureau, to ensure the safety of luggage pass without damage​

 

Intelligent control, secure connection​

 

APP control, deal with any unexpected situation​

 

Adjustable tie rod design, in line with ergonomic concept, make your towing more comfortable​

 

20 inches available capacity, let you level separately, no longer messy​

 

360 degree mute aircraft wheel (Wan Xianglun), 360 degree flexible steering

 

High precision double bearing structure, better damping buffer, the box is no longer damaged​

 

The space is compact and methodical​

 

Retro style leather hasp, soft and comfortable​

Independent research and development of bags, zippers, electronic locks, bags, electromechanical hasp locks and other professional technology, let us better design and improve products, in the road of innovation go a long way.

story:
Risks & Challenges

         Throughout the research and development phase of creating Mountain Pong, the team faced numerous challenges such as type of plastic to use, plastic density, type of mold to use, and the overall design of Mountain Pong (including angles for cups and stack-ability concerns). The Mountain Pong team persevered to bring a high quality product to the consumer at a reasonable price. Additionally, every part of Mountain Pong is made in America! Our manufacturing and logistics supply chains are ready to fill your orders. We are excited to serve you. With your help, we can bring Mountain Pong to new heights. Aim Higher!

story:
Product Features

About Us

Branding and identity


People often ask what NXTPACK means. To us, it stands for the next big thing.
Our slogan, Best Backpack Engineered , demonstrates our focus on real people in real world scenarios. Our designs are based on comfort, function and safety, and our processes take into account the interaction between all three and the people who stand to benefit from them.


NXTPACK is a start-up subsidiary of the already established WenPod brand - Digital Stabilizer (www.wenpod.com) . In order to broaden our high reputation in consumer electronics, we’ve been developing a new line of backpacks.

We chose to launch this as a crowdfunding project because we believe it has the greatest potential to reach more customers and allow us to introduce you to our work ethic, standards and immense pride in delivering the best quality products we can to the people who share our passion.

Why crowdfunding?

 

Like all innovations that have come before, it started with ‘what if?’


Something as simple as a backpack is quite often taken for granted. We see it as something simply designed to get the job done, but what if it could be something more than that?
What if your backpack is putting you at risk of being targeted by thieves?
What if it was somewhere you could turn when your phone runs out of juice?
What if you had a way of keeping your belongings safe, organized and always within reach?
What if you could keep your camera at arm’s length and never miss that one-in-a-lifetime shot?
What if your phone and passport were on hand in seconds but always totally secure?
These were the questions that crept up again and again after spending an entire year observing the habits of people who travel. That’s why we designed Urbanvibe as a one-size-fits-all solution.
NXTPACK’s vision for a true anti-theft backpack was more than a bulky and unsightly travel bag. We wanted assurances of security, convenience, comfort and elegance. And so, we turn to crowdfunding as an opportunity to share this vision of a better lifestyle with you.

 

Risks and challenges

As innovators, the greatest challenge to the birth of new ideas is time. It’s the difference between a concept being abandoned and a new product infiltrating and indeed changing the market.
We have gone to great lengths to mitigate that risk by choosing to work exclusively with high-end suppliers and meticulously planning our timeline for any eventuality, ensuring we can confidently meet the timelines and promises outlined in our manifesto without incident.
Our stringent quality assurance team place great emphasis on thoroughly inspecting every order to guarantee each one meets our high standards and all backers receive their rewards without defects.
These measures allow us to remain optimistic about fulfilling whatever demands are made of us and not only meeting but exceeding deadlines.
